posts.title: Roads of Kiarostami
posts.excerpt: جاده‌های کیارستمی Abbas Kiarostami has recently been exhibiting his black-and-white landscape photographs at venues around the world, and Roads of Kiarostami is both a companion piece to these exhibits and an extension of them. Static shots of his photos alternate with footage of Kiarostami’s car winding through mountain roads, as the Iranian filmmaker muses in …

posts._title: Rüdiger Suchsland – Hitlers Hollywood AKA Hitler‘s Hollywood (2017)
posts.title: Hitlers Hollywood
posts.excerpt: This documentary examines the German cinema from 1933 when the Nazi’s came into power until 1945 when the Third Reich collapsed.

posts.title: The Lady Vanishes
posts.excerpt: Quote: In this best-loved of Hitchcock’s British-made thrillers, a young woman on a train meets a charming old lady (Dame May Whitty), who promptly disappears. The other passengers deny ever having seen her, leading the young woman to suspect a conspiracy. When she begins investigating, she is drawn into a complex web of mystery and …

posts._title: Noburô Ôfuji – A Story of Tobacco (1926)
posts.title: A Story of Tobacco
posts.excerpt: A tiny man explains the origins of tobacco to a young woman.

posts.title: Fitzcarraldo
posts.excerpt: Synopsis: Klaus Kinski plays the title role of an obsessed opera lover who wants to build an opera in the jungle. To accomplish this he first has to make a fortune in the rubber business, and his cunning plan involves hauling an enormous river boat across a small mountain with aid from the local indians.

posts._title: Kieron J. Walsh – James Joyce: A Shout in the Street (2017)
posts.title: James Joyce: A Shout in the Street
posts.excerpt: James Joyce is widely regarded as one of the most important writers of the last century. His most famous novel, Ulysses, may be demanding of its readers, but it is also regarded as one of the most influential books ever written. In this documentary, James Joyce: A Shout in the Street, Anjelica Huston tells the …

posts._title: Júlio Bressane – Barão Olavo, o Horrível (1970)
posts.title: Barão Olavo, o Horrível
posts.excerpt: Bressane’s first color film, shot in the home of the artist Elyseu Visconti. Part of it is missing sound and final editing because the director was forced to leave Brazil. Horror and humor to deal with the subject of insanity: “In the end everyone leaves the house as though they were laboratory mice escaping, they …

posts.title: The Executioner’s Song
posts.excerpt: Quote: The Executioner’s Song is one of the best films about crime and punishment ever made. Far from being lurid or simpleminded, it paints a stark picture of how it must have been to live around Gilmore during that time. It doesn’t glamorize him or turn him into a cardboard villain, but instead depicts him …

posts.title: Rebecca
posts.excerpt: Quote: Rebecca is a 1940 psychological/dramatic noir thriller directed by Alfred Hitchcock as his first American project, and his first film produced under his contract with David O. Selznick. The film’s screenplay was an adaptation by Joan Harrison and Robert E. Sherwood from Philip MacDonald and Michael Hogan’s adaptation of Daphne du Maurier’s 1938 novel …

posts._title: Abdellatif Kechiche – La graine et le mulet AKA The Secret of the Grain (2007)
posts.title: La graine et le mulet
posts.excerpt: Quote: The winner of four César awards, including best picture and director, Abdellatif Kechiche’s The Secret of the Grain is a stirring drama about the daily joys and struggles of a bustling French-Arab family. It has the texture of a documentary but a classic, almost Shakespearean structure: when patriarch Slimane acts on his wish to …
